name: Frequent leader changes seen in last minute
description: Detects high number of leader changes in last minute

fields.name: content
fields.value:
1. Increase the election timeout value: By default, the election timeout is set to 10 seconds. You can increase this value to 30 seconds or more to prevent frequent leader changes. To do this, modify the `etcdctl` configuration by executing the following command:
```
etcdctl set /etc/etcd/etcd.conf election-timeout=30
```
2. Check for network connectivity issues: Frequent leader changes could be caused by network connectivity problems. Ensure that all nodes in the cluster have proper network connectivity and are able to communicate with each other.
3. Monitor the cluster health: Regularly monitor the health of the etcd cluster using tools like Prometheus or Grafana. This will help identify any potential issues before they become critical.
4. Update the etcd version: If the problem persists, consider updating the etcd version to the latest stable release. Sometimes, compatibility issues between versions can cause unexpected behavior.
5. Reconfigure the cluster: In case of severe performance issues or network instability, you may need to reconfigure the cluster by adding more nodes or changing the data distribution strategy.

By following these steps, you should be able to improve the stability of your etcd cluster and reduce the frequency of leader changes.
